title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement explore.statistics@education.gov.uk. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to eesyscreener
text: Ideas eesyscreener first raised GitHub issue anyone free write code create pull request review.

title: Contributing to eesyscreener
text: Explore education statistics (EES) bespoke statistics publishing platform, work rely standardising structure data files. package contains checks used enforce open data standards. expect package serve following purposes: - Provide.. - file validation EES, documentation validation - checks used R Shiny screener app used analysts check files - Allow analysts… - check files R using screen_files() - reuse individual check_* functions QA pipelines

title: Contributing to eesyscreener
text: screen_files() pulls together currently main export individual checks copied screener named check_* check_* functions must return consistent list structure File structure - one script per check_* function (except R/utils.R) R/utils.R contains internal functions R/data-raw.R contains source code example data hardcoded variables Use RDS main format shrink test data (beware automatically cleaning!), use CSV make data.frame() code needed Think dependencies functions - can pass results pre-requisites functions? avoid heavy dependencies performance profile use fastest available functions TODO: end moving checks set tests screen_tests() run example test data

what: Process for moving in functions from app
title: Contributing to eesyscreener
text: Tracking spreadsheet set sharepoint, contains table checks, thoughts new groupings notes migration (including progress). Example adding new check available PR XX Tackle one screening check time (unless can create one function covers multiple repeated checks) Set new script test script check, copy relevant code https://github.com/dfe-analytical-services/dfe-published-data-qa Add test data fail function Make use tests/utils/copy_check_data.R script copy CSVs screener repo save RDS files tests folder collection unit tests least one example data file expected failure every function Adapt function input arguments outputs match existing check_* functions Integrate new check_* screen_files() function Document code inheriting documentation existing functions possible lot functions package, want minimise amount duplicated code. Use @inheritParams function_name copy param definitions another Functions check standard param definitions: - check_empty_cols - check_filename_spaces Use #' @inherit check_empty_cols return copy return documentation functions setup, review improve code Make sure tests passing ’ve commited point ensure don’t inadvertently break anything! Create use helper functions (haven’t already), place helper functions R/utils.R, mark @keywords internal Avoid bringing many new dependencies, try rewriting base R possible Use microbenchmark experiment find efficient approach (speed king ) e.g. example, first line requires janitor package. slightly faster mean 115ms, second line mean 184ms, third line mean 121ms, ’s minimal amount 1 3, usually ’d go option 3 avoid needing call janitor package dependency, keeping package lightweight. However, testing bigger file (~6million rows), 2nd 3rd options slow run microbenchmark taking long produce result. Clearly using janitor option 1 massive impact ’s rows, decision made import janitor package speed benefit worth extra dependency. can use tests/utils/benchmarking.R script starting point, includes code generate big tables run benchmarking. Sometimes fastest small files fastest bigger ones. Prioritise bigger files ’s biggest impact felt. ’s particularly big function running whole data file, also consider using future.apply parallel processing approaches swap easily.
code: data <- eesyscreener::example_data  microbenchmark::microbenchmark(   nrow(data) - nrow(janitor::remove_empty(data, which = "rows", quiet = TRUE)),   sum(apply(data, 1, function(row) all(is.na(row) | row == ""))),   sum(rowSums(is.na(data) | data == "") == ncol(data)),   times = 100000 )  ## NOTE: This particular check was removed as other checks will cover it ## - check_time_periods ## - check_meta_col_type

what: List of notes for the main screener

text: TODO: Move images screenFiles server part app TODO: Move character forcing columns within screen files function TODO: Update test data testing approach

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cam Race. Author, maintainer. Department Education, England. Copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Race C (2025). eesyscreener: Explore education statistics data screening. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://dfe-analytical-services.github.io/eesyscreener/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {eesyscreener: Explore education statistics data screening},   author = {Cam Race},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://dfe-analytical-services.github.io/eesyscreener/}, }

title: Explore education statistics data screening
text: Quality assurance checks used screen files standards required official statistics files explore education statistics (EES) platform.

title: Explore education statistics data screening
text: eesyscreener currently available CRAN. time can install development version GitHub.
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("dfe-analytical-services/eesyscreener")

title: Explore education statistics data screening
text: shows quick reproducible example can run console test . also shows example output structure core screen_files() function.
code: library(eesyscreener)  screen_files(   "data.csv",   "data.meta.csv",   example_data, # replace with your data file   example_meta # replace with your meta file ) #> $results_table #>                   check result #> 1 check_filename_spaces   PASS #> 2 check_filename_spaces   PASS #> 3      check_empty_cols   PASS #>                                                 message stage #> 1      'data.csv' does not have spaces in the filename.     1 #> 2 'data.meta.csv' does not have spaces in the filename.     1 #> 3           'data.csv' does not have any blank columns.     1 #>  #> $overall_stage #> [1] "Passed" #>  #> $overall_message #> [1] "Passed all checks"

title: Explore education statistics data screening
text: Quick examples make use data within package generate CSVs testing: available example files can found documentation site examples. Use write.csv() examples generate CSVs .
code: library(eesyscreener)  write.csv(example_data, "example_data.csv", row.names = FALSE) write.csv(example_meta, "example_data.meta.csv", row.names = FALSE)  # Generate a file pairing that will fail the tests (spaces in filename) write.csv(example_data, "example data.csv", row.names = FALSE) write.csv(example_meta, "example data.meta.csv", row.names = FALSE)

title: Explore education statistics data screening
text: want generate larger files testing , can use generate_test_dfs() function create files number time periods, locations, filters indicators. want go really big, combine dfeR package, pass vectors Parliamentary Constituencies, data.table much faster CSV creation. following example creates example data metadata pair data set just 6 million rows. Formula calculate rows : length(years) * length(pcon_codes) * (5 ^ num_filters)
code: files <- eesyscreener::generate_test_dfs(   years = 2013:2015,    pcon_names = "Sheffield Central",    pcon_codes = "E14000919",    num_filters = 2,    num_indicators = 3 )  # Data and metadata are returned in a list, to extract: df <- files$data df_meta <- files$meta # Load this eesyscreener package devtools::load_all()  # Additional dependencies library("dfeR") library("data.table")  # Get a data frame of all Parliamentary Constituencies in England pcons <- dfeR::fetch_pcons(countries = "England")  # As this is generating a big file, and isn't overly optimised, it may take a minute or two beefy <- eesyscreener::generate_test_dfs(   years = c(1980:2025),   pcon_codes = pcons$pcon_code,   pcon_names = pcons$pcon_name,   num_filters = 3,   num_indicators = 45,   verbose = TRUE )  # Then to create CSVs, use data.table as it's much faster data.table::fwrite(beefy$data, "beefy_data.csv") data.table::fwrite(beefy$meta, "beefy_data.meta.csv")

title: Check for empty columns — check_empty_cols
text: function checks empty cols given data frame returns list check result message.

title: Check for empty columns — check_empty_cols
code: check_empty_cols(df, filename = NULL)

title: Check for empty columns — check_empty_cols
text: df data frame check filename character string filename check

title: Check for empty columns — check_empty_cols
text: list containing: check Character string stage check belongs . result Character string, either "PASS", "FAIL" "ADVISORY". message Character string feedback check.

title: Check for empty columns — check_empty_cols
text: Filename optional used populate feedback message.

title: Check for empty columns — check_empty_cols
code: df <- eesyscreener::example_data check_empty_cols(df, "datafile.csv") #> $check #> [1] "check_empty_cols" #>  #> $result #> [1] "PASS" #>  #> $message #> [1] "'datafile.csv' does not have any blank columns." #>  check_empty_cols(df) #> $check #> [1] "check_empty_cols" #>  #> $result #> [1] "PASS" #>  #> $message #> [1] "the tested data frame does not have any blank columns." #>

what: Check for spaces in filename — check_filename_spaces
title: Check for spaces in filename — check_filename_spaces
text: function checks provided filename contains spaces.

title: Check for spaces in filename — check_filename_spaces
code: check_filename_spaces(filename)

title: Check for spaces in filename — check_filename_spaces
text: filename character string filename check

title: Check for spaces in filename — check_filename_spaces
text: list containing: check Character string stage check belongs . result Character string, either "PASS", "FAIL" "ADVISORY". message Character string feedback check.

title: Check for spaces in filename — check_filename_spaces
code: check_filename_spaces("datafile.csv") #> $check #> [1] "check_filename_spaces" #>  #> $result #> [1] "PASS" #>  #> $message #> [1] "'datafile.csv' does not have spaces in the filename." #>  check_filename_spaces("data file.meta.csv") #> $check #> [1] "check_filename_spaces" #>  #> $result #> [1] "FAIL" #>  #> $message #> [1] "There are spaces that need removing in 'data file.meta.csv' (filename)." #>

title: Example data — example_data
text: Simple example data file.

title: Example data — example_data
code: example_data

title: Example data — example_data
text: data frame 9 rows 8 columns: time_period Time period row time_identifier Time identifier row geographic_level Geographic level row country_code Country code (9 digits) country_name Country name sex Sex pupil education_phase Phase education enrolment_count Number enrolments

title: Example data — example_data
text: maintained explore.statistics@education.gov.uk

title: Example filter group data — example_filter_group
text: Simple example data file showing example filter groups action

title: Example filter group data — example_filter_group

what: Run all checks against files — screen_files
title: Run all checks against files — screen_files
text: Run checks eesyscreener package data file associated metadata file. parses files runs checks four stages, function return early check stage fails.

title: Run all checks against files — screen_files
code: screen_files(datafilename, metafilename, datafile, metafile, api_only = FALSE)

title: Run all checks against files — screen_files
text: datafilename name data file. metafilename name metadata file. datafile data frame containing data file contents. metafile data frame containing metadata file contents. api_only Logical value indicating whether run API checks.

title: Run all checks against files — screen_files
text: list containing table full results checks four columns: result check (PASS / FAIL / ADVISORY) message giving feedback check stage check belongs name check Overall stage checks reached Overall message give back user

title: Run all checks against files — screen_files
code: screen_files(   "data.csv",   "data.meta.csv",   example_data,   example_meta ) #> $results_table #>                   check result #> 1 check_filename_spaces   PASS #> 2 check_filename_spaces   PASS #> 3      check_empty_cols   PASS #>                                                 message stage #> 1      'data.csv' does not have spaces in the filename.     1 #> 2 'data.meta.csv' does not have spaces in the filename.     1 #> 3           'data.csv' does not have any blank columns.     1 #>  #> $overall_stage #> [1] "Passed" #>  #> $overall_message #> [1] "Passed all checks" #>
